Award.AwardTitle: CONFERENCE: Southeastern Regional Yeast Meeting to be held at Rhodes College; March 9-11, 2018

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports Southeastern Regional Yeast Meeting (SERYM) to be held March 9-11, 2018 on the campus of Rhodes College in Memphis, TN. SERYM provides a forum for discussion of topics in yeast molecular and cellular biology, such as transcription and RNA processing, signal transduction and growth control, chromatin remodeling and epigenetics, chromosome dynamics, telomere biology, genome integrity, DNA transactions, damage and repair, RNA metabolism, and cell cycle regulation. A multi-level perspective is provided by also including posters and presentations on yeast molecular ecology and evolutionary biology.

The regional meetings in a compact setting, with small overall participation (< 125 expected) and high attendance by undergraduate researchers, many from the EPSCoR states or from predominantly undergraduate institutions, offer an excellent opportunity for student researchers to report their findings and exchange scientific ideas with more senior scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 25th Annual Southeastern Regional Yeast Meeting was held March 9-11, 2018 on the campus of Rhodes College. This conference is an opportunity for researchers from predominantly the Southeastern United States to come together to share research results, techniques, and ideas as they relate to the use of yeasts as model organisms. These single-celled organisms are ideal for understanding complex biological processes due to their relative ease of growth and genetic manipulation. Researchers studying these simple eukaryotes have made significant contributions in areas as diverse as fungal evolution, DNA damage/repair, gene expression, RNA processing, cell cycle progression, chromosome segregation, prion propagation, autophagy, and organelle biogenesis/maintenance. During the course of the meeting, over 20 individual research talks were given on topics ranging from DNA damage and repair to fundamental aspects of overall yeast cellular biology.

This National Science Foundation supported project awarded travel funds for 20 undergraduate and graduate students from 12 different institutions to attend the meeting and present their work. Reflecting the unique nature of the meeting, 12 of the awardees were undergraduates from predominantly undergraduate institutions giving these students the opportunity to meet and discuss their work with graduate students and faculty from research intensive institutions. Graduate trainees had the opportunity to present their work to colleagues from other institutions and begin collaborations with other scientists that will carry through their careers moving forward. Collectively the meeting was a rewarding educational experience for both trainees and faculty in attendance.
